headline: Trump unveils 'America first' national security strategy
subHeadline: President outlines plan that includes defeating ISIS, protecting the homeland from North Korea and securing U.S. borders.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Kimberly Guilfoyle along with Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." This is a Fox News alert: President Trump has unveiled his strategy for national security, one that enshrines his America First campaign approach as U.S. policy. In an address at the Ronald Reagan building in Washington, the president outlined a plan that includes defeating ISIS, protecting the U.S. from North Korea and securing our borders among other topics. The president also spoke about living a greater America to our children and our grandchildren. utterances.sentences: No. No, I watched -- it was some -- I watched a documentary.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It is. You see it in a documentary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Big weekend plans, huh, Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know it. All right. Up next, the real-life hunt for E.T. Glad they're going after that punk. New details about a $20 million top- secret military UFO program when we return.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh. I guess we're not alone after all. A stunning new revelation. The Pentagon reportedly set up a secret program ten years ago looking for UFOs deep in space. And newly-released video captured by U.S. Navy pilots offers an inside look at this secretive government program. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There's a whole fleet of them. Look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: My gosh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: "My gosh" is right. I mean, who would believe? So the thing is, we don't know if this is a UFO. It could be, like, somebody's aircraft that wasn't reported. But this really gives a lot of credence to people who've been saying, "Hey, the government was hiding something from us." You're shaking your head?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, because we already know there's nothing out there because a couple of reasons. One, we have had this incredible revolution with digital cameras and smartphones. We spend all this time looking -- as a child, looking at these grainy photographs that we used to look at as kids and documentaries. Well, we don't get any more of that. And people -- everybody has a phone, and we don't see anymore. The reason why there has been no contact is because they aren't -- they do not exist. And they don't exist, because we don't exist. We go out and we look at the lifeless orbs, these planets out there, that's what we look like to them, because this is is all a computer simulation that basically was created long ago. Those planets out there are already conquered and simulated, which is why there's only us.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is he OK?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I just changed my mind. I think Greg is an alien. I think you're the alien.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I am a shapeshifting lizard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. Well, anyway...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Now you're going to encourage people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I was struck that in fact, you know, ten years, and they put 22 million bucks into this, Dana. So do you think this is a waste, or does this justify what the government was doing?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: In the scheme of things, for as much money as the government spends, I think that this is not money that was poorly spent. I do think that it was -- it was Harry Reid, the senator from Nevada, who got this money earmarked into the DIA budget, which is a secret budget for the intelligence agencies and the Defense Department. But he had support from Senator Ted Stevens, who said, "I think we ought to look into this."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, why? Because he got hit by a UFO.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was an unidentified flying object.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You mean Harry Reid?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, when he...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hurt his eye.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. The exercise equipment?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I liked that joke.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I listened to an interview this morning with -- on "The Daily," the New York Times podcast. They interviewed the guy who just recently left his position. What was he, Ando (ph), I think his name was?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And he says, like -- he's not saying there's for sure something out there but that it's definitely worth studying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But Jesse, there was the video. It's not like we don't know. I mean, now you're looking at something just like the pilot, and you're saying what is that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I can't identify what that is, Juan. I have no idea. But I've gone to these UFO conventions back in the day and shot "Watters' World," and people tell me stories about being abducted.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: They believe any of this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They honestly believe they were abducted and things were done to them while aboard the spacecraft. And a lot of the stories share similar details. So there has to be something going on. I don't think everybody is hallucinating.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, they are. It's hypnogogic nightmares. Everybody, they're hypnogogic nightmares. When you're in sleep paralysis, and you think something is on top of you, that's a hypnogogic nightmare.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But I do think spending a lot of money on stuff like this has other benefits. You know? Like obviously, when the military industrial complex spends this amount of money on things, isn't that how they created the Internet? Not Al Gore.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, that's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You never know what you might discover.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What you just said is absolutely true. But Kimberly, I'm accustomed to sort of mocking these people as tin hat -- tinfoil hat brigade, I think they call them, or people who are just making -- you know, if you ever listen to Art Bell in the middle of the night on the radio. All these things, you think what? This guys is -- but he's entertaining. Now I'm thinking maybe there's something going on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, look, there's been enough discussion about it that it makes sense they're going to study it or figure it out. Even President Trump said he wants to know about, you know, Area 51 and the secrets of it. It was, like, a good reason to become president, right, get all the top-secret information. Just like with the JFK files. I don't know. I mean, listen, I have an open mind about things. I also enjoy astrology.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Very nice. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What's your sign?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Pisces.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Ooh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Time for...

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Talking Animal News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Talking Animal News." You know, working at FOX, a lot of people send me some interesting things. I'll get something like leather socks one day, and then I'll get homemade meat the next, which I love to eat so keep sending it. And every now and then I get a talking animal. And somebody sent me a -- looks like I believe it might be a hamster. And it had an interesting message for us. Roll it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm Jesse Watters the hamster. I have 27 brothers and sisters. And my mom still hates me the most.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very good, Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I wonder if it's somebody we know who sent that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jerry Pentacoli (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't get it. Whoever sent it is probably on some kind of power trip.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's pretty cute, though, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So today marks the 20th anniversary of the death of one of our favorite comedians. Christopher Farley. That's right, died of a drug overdose in his apartment at age 33. You know, "SNL" guy, was along with Chris Rock, Adam Sandler, Rob Schneider, David Spade and one of my favorite movies, "Tommy Boy."

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER FARLEY, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: Fat guy in a little coat. Fat guy in a little coat.

utterances.speaker: DAVID SPADE, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: I'm serious.

utterances.speaker: FARLEY
utterances.sentences: Richard, what's happening? Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We all still miss him today. And he appeared in a lot of "Watters' Worlds." So thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Aww. Sweet, Jesse. You're touched.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Literally.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Careful.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You're waiting on me. All right. Visions of sugar plums dancing in your head for the holidays? Well, not so much for Luke Skywalker, a.k.a. actor Mark Hamill. He's still upset that the FCC voted last week to repeal net neutrality. He's particularly incensed that the FCC chairman, Ajit Pai, dressed up as a Jedi in a video to endorse the repeal. Hamill tweeted at him, saying, "You are profoundly unworthy to wield a lightsaber. A Jedi you are not."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my. The force is not with you, Mr. Chairman.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: How crazy is that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They really are picking on that guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're going after his family.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Remember, not only a Jedi; he dressed up as Santa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They guy -- they hate him more than they hate ISIS. It's ridiculous, these people.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's so nuts. OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. So you know most babies start walking around the age of 1. But Cash Rally thought that was too easy. Check her out. So she started -- she's from Idaho. She started walking at nine months. And her parents are big outdoor enthusiasts, so they had her get on a snowboard and took it around the house, and then she hit the slopes. And she was able to do it at 1 years old.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Check her out. Cash Rally. And they're going to try to go to Costa Rica in February and get her up on surfboard, too. So we look forward to those.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No helmet?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She's pretty good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No helmet? Oh, it's just a baby with a soft head. Yes, that's smart.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She's pretty cute.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Helmets are for snowflakes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nicely done.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh. These two, sensitivity training. OK, perfect. So I have a book to promote. No, not one of my own, like Greg does. But one for Chris McKinley, former Navy SEAL, and Andy Simon. They have a new book out called "Enemy in the Wire." And it's perfect for anyone interested in military life, specifically. Andy grew up in a navy family. And then, as I said, Chris is one of our fearless warriors with the Navy SEALs. And it's a follow-up to Andy's first novel. "My Father's Son" is a behind-the-scenes look at the Special Ops community and what it takes to be part of that brotherhood and tells the story of one boy, of one family who has their world ripped apart by war. It's actually going to be preordered on Amazon, but it's out officially in March, just in time for my birthday. Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Are we going to get some tattoos now, everybody?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm in. I'm not in, no. I'll watch you guys get them, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tattoo night. We should have a tattoo night.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I actually think the one that makes the most sense is...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Gorka?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think we should all get matching Gorka. Yes. Jesse, you go first.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Where's the booze?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" up next. Bret, take it away. You in? Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Kimberly Guilfoyle along with Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five."

utterances.speaker: This is a Fox News alert
utterances.utterance: President Trump has unveiled his strategy for national security, one that enshrines his America First campaign approach as U.S. policy. In an address at the Ronald Reagan building in Washington, the president outlined a plan that includes defeating ISIS, protecting the U.S. from North Korea and securing our borders among other topics. The president also spoke about living a greater America to our children and our grandchildren. Watch.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: On top of everything else, our leaders drifted from American principles. They lost sight of America's destiny and they lost their belief in American greatness. On January 20, 2017, I stood on the steps of the capital. To herald the day the people became the rulers of their nation again. American success is not a foregone conclusion. It must be earned and it must be won. Together we will leave our children and grandchildren a nation that is stronger, better, freer, prouder and yes, an America that is greater than ever before.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Greg, I know what you're going to say so I can't call on you right now. Dana?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, our national security strategy is something that is congressionally mandated, but a president could wait a couple, three years even before they do something. And I think that any president that puts out a plan, like that's the plan until breaking news changes everything.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . which is -- you never know what's going to pop up in the world. And every problem in the world ends up on the president's desk. There's two things that I really liked about it. In particular, you're going to see a push about this next year and we need to talk about it more, which is military readiness and the state of our military, repairs that are needed for our planes and new planes that are needed, the new equipment. And also, all the cybersecurity issues that we're dealing with. The president touched on that a little bit, and I think you'll see a push in the New Year, especially when it comes to funding. The other thing that I like to hearing him say was that as a force for good throughout its history, America will use influence -- it's influence to advance our interests and benefit humanity, and I think that really does keeps us separate from other countries in he world. That we are exceptional for a reason and that really is the main reason.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. So you liked it? I mean, definitely seems you thought about American exceptionalism.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean the thought of it made sense to me. Like, protecting the homeland.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . I get it. American prosperity. If America is doing better economically, that means you have more money in the world and more influence and more money to pay for military readiness in order to protect the country, and also economic freedom is a part of that. Preserve peace through strength and advance American influence. If you're just reading it that way, you could say any president over the past 200 years could have had similar things.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When he talked about it in -- you heard like the sort of first half of the speech was really going through the list of accomplishments that he thinks he's had over this past year, and then he got to the strategies. So, it all fitted together at the end, but for me the two things that stood out the most was military readiness, which we know we have a huge problem with and that has to get fix, and the second piece being this -- saying that we will continue to be a force for good in the world, which the world needs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, Greg, you heard some different things as well in there.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No, I heard kind of the same things. I mean, I'm always tired of hearing it's always about the children.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I'm OK with that. This is a central piece of his agenda. I called it the stool of security. So, it's a table with three legs. One of them is national security, dealing with our enemies and adversaries like ISIS north and North Korea. Then you have domestic security, which is basically reinvigorating the way the country feels and appreciate law enforcement because we've saw them disrespected for so long. And the third is the border, which is linked to the above. The border becomes more valuable in terms of national security when you have terrorism and you have technologies. Those are the three legs on this stool. But the big point here is, somewhere along the line is government grew we've lost the plot. What is government for, primarily? This. Without this, the stool of security, you don't have freedom or prosperity. Security and strength guarantees freedom and prosperity. The last thing, politically, is that if you don't like Trump or you just couldn't get -- you just couldn't accept him, this is a kind of agenda that makes you overlook the small stuff that bugs you. You know what I mean. I've said this before, if somebody is right on the big picture, you can forgive or overlook the smaller, more embarrassing Polaroids. You know, so what if he tweets and there's always this kind of underlying chaos and conflict. Somebody is right on the big picture, it doesn't matter. When we look back, we will realize that it didn't matter. No one will remember a lot of this stuff. But we will remember the strong military and enhanced security and no terrorism.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, great point. This immigration and border protection are also key components of President Trump's new national security strategy. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Leaders in Washington imposed on the country an immigration policy that Americans never voted for, never asked for, and never approved. A policy where the wrong people are allowed into our country, and the right people are rejected. American citizens as usual have been left to bear the cost and to pick up the tab. A nation without borders is not a nation.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, Jesse, your reaction to this.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I think he was trying to strike a very clean break from past administrations by saying he's here to ignite a reawakening in American confidence, and usher in a rebirth of pride and patriotism and prosperity by putting America first and putting the people above the powerful, and American greatness has to be guarded vigilantly because our destiny is not assured. And he tried to inspire all the American people to be competitive in a new competitive world, and pointed out China and Russia as other great nations that are trying to see is what we have. And then he pointed to all the litany of failures from past administrations, taxpayers bailing out other alliances, jobs being fleeced by overseas out of country, spending a lot of blood and treasure on wars where we tied. And he went along that list but then like Greg said, pointed out to the four pillars. Protect the homeland, and you just heard him. Border security, and that's the wall. That's reinforcing our great border patrol agents, and that's getting rid of things like chain migration and the visa lottery. Also, defeating ISIS and make sure they can't come over here. But then promoting peace and prosperity, and that's through cutting taxes and cutting regulations. And not signing bad trade deals where workers get hosed and big companies make out great, and then preserving peace through strength. Taking about a huge reinvestment in our military, but also focusing on modern threats like missile-defense and cyber. And then at the end, he kind of tweaked President Obama, he's trying to focus on realism, not idealism. We're not going to try to impose our way of life on other people, and we're not going to lead from behind, so we're going to champion our values, and I think he believes that's the best opportunity for us to maintain our number one posture.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Loves being number one, Jesse. OK. So Juan, did you hear this through the same prism that Jesse did?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Not at all. I certainly agree with Jesse that he was playing against, you know, grievance politics, going at all the presidents who came before, when in fact this -- I think, I think somebody else in the panel, maybe you, Dana, said it could be any other president. This is basically in keeping with our national security framework.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, she said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But where it differs, and to me he identified it. So you've got to give him credit for that. Is that China and Russia are exerting increasing evidence that they want to increase their profile in the world globally. So to me, if you look at Asia where we backed out of the Asian trade deal, I see China stepping up, and it's not only stepping up in terms of economics but militarily. Similarly, Russia in the Middle East, given what happened in Syria but also with Iran. You see Russia playing a bigger role. So Trump identifies that, but he then doesn't say exactly how we will respond. To the contrary, he says we're going to be more focused on our interests and our security. Well, of course, he's going to focus on our security, but I don't see that we are taking the necessary steps to fight back against Russia and China's growing influence in the world. I was out at that Reagan library the other day for the national defense forum, and this is what the defense experts are saying, is that there's a lot of talk from Trump, a lot of rhetoric, but no action in terms of saying here is what our Middle East policies is going to be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But this is -- he is reprioritizing. The number one threat isn't Russia, the number one threat isn't China, its existential terror. That's the ball that he sees. These other things are behind that ball and he will deal with them, and maybe they can help. Maybe Russia can help with terror. When you look at it from that angle, that's what happens.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't agree with you. And by the way, there was an interesting phone call over the weekend between Trump and Putin, where Putin thanked, apparently, Trump for intelligence that boarded attacks that would have taken place in St. Petersburg. But I don't think that terror is the number one issue here. If you're talking about our national security structure, I think you are talking about the possibility that terror would be generated in a place like the Middle East, especially after what he did with Jerusalem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, President Trump also addressed the strategic goal of the U.S., which was destroying ISIS.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We have dealt ISIS one devastating defeat after another. The correlation to defeat ISIS has now recaptured almost 100 percent of the land once held by these terrorists in Iraq and in Syria. Great job.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We're now chasing them wherever they flee, and we will not let them into the United States.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. So focus now on our national security, obviously, on borders, a strong immigration policy, peace through strength. Echoes some of the comments you made earlier about former presidents, past presidents really focusing on this, kind of Reaganesque theme, and then here, using a specific example, talk extensive, ISIS.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. I do think that technology has advanced so much in -- just in 16 years. And one of the things that you can do is shrink ISIS's territory. You can even prevent them from getting in here. But we have shown in just the last months that we continue to have a problem with online radicalization. So, ISIS is able still to put videos online to try to figure out a way to get to people. And the president is saying, OK, the first thing we have to do as a part of America first is figure out a way to use the tools that we have been in order to prevent that from happening. He doesn't spell it all out in here, and you can't in a national security document. A lot of these stuff has to be classified. But I do think that he will have to have quite a strong push, and probably you'll see it in the state of the union, that military readiness which includes dealing with possibilities of biological terror, online terror attacks like cyberattacks. And then, you had somebody like China just to pull this all together, as that what Juan was talking about. This morning, China released a huge plan for its government to be the number one artificial intelligence creator and technology developer in the world. So they're like way ahead in terms of that type of planning, and we don't want to be playing second fiddle to that. So there's a lot that's going to happen. And I think this next year, in fact, you set the stage for how are you going to provide the resources to our military and intelligence forces in order to do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Those resources, $700 billion investment, that's a historic investment in the U.S. military. And to Juan's point, I mean, he's ripped up the rules of engagement which allowed us to destroy the caliphate over there. No artificial timelines in Afghanistan. The Iran revolutionary guard is now labeled as a terrorist organization. That bad deal is also in the cross hairs. And the North Korea situation, major sanctions slapped on them. So to say that the president isn't really doing anything or hasn't really spelled out how he's doing it. Juan, you want to remain unpredictable, but I think there's a lot of leather out there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't remember which Sunday show, yesterday. It was pretty funny. They're interviewing some dude, some expert, and he was talking about -- beginning about how Trump had a bad year. Trump had a bad year except for ISIS. Except for ISIS. The economy is doing pretty good. (INAUDIBLE) But he had a really bad year. Yeah, except for ISIS. It's like, if all he did was ISIS, that's a pretty damn great year. But the way, we had other news today -- I don't know how true it is, but what a difference from Obama who gave a pass to Hezbollah. I'm not sure if that's true, but it's something that maybe we should look into.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you guys should pick up a copy of a newspaper and in it would say, oh, my gosh. Look, President Bush, President Obama, all of these people were fighting terror all along.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what Politico said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. That's what you say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Was it Politico?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So it wasn't crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It was crazy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you like Politico.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And Bret Baier is going to have a big thing on it tonight, that very story.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So there you go. That's deep tease. Coming up, President Trump says he's not happy with the way the Mueller investigation is being handled. You're going to hear his plans on dealing with the special counsel, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a big week on Capitol Hill as key players in the FBI and Justice Department are testifying before lawmakers. Sources tell Fox News, Bruce Ohr, who the DOJ recently demoted is being questioned today in a closed-door hearing about Fusion GPS. And tomorrow, deputy FBI director Andrew McCabe is set to appear before the house intelligence committee. This weekend, President Trump doubled down on saying there is no collusion with Russia.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Not looking good. Not looking good. It's quite sad to see that. My people were very upset about it. I can't imagine there's anything on him, frankly, because as we said, there's no collusion. There's no collusion whatsoever. But a lot of lawyers thought that was pretty sad.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. So Gutfeld, let's start with the Mueller firing. In the beginning of the weekend, it was -- he's going to fire Robert Mueller, and in the end, he wasn't. What was that all about?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it's great. On twitter all these celebrities were threatening to take to the streets, blamed on a rumor that they probably started. They go, oh, my God. He's going to fire Mueller. Let's go to the street. Who told you that? Well, the other guy on twitter told me that. This is a real boring version of the Hatfield and the McCoy's. The media and the Democrats were the Hatfield's. They just never expected the McCoy's to show up. It's always been a one-sided fight. So now they have, like, OK, you've got collusion. We yell corruption. You yell Russia. We yelled deep state. It's a lot of energy. It's like a game of tic-tac-toe that always ends in cat. It allows two sides to dig in. And I really do think this cancels each other out. Both sides has got to go like that, it's a push.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the first question he was asked by reporters when he was wearing that Amazing USA hat, Kimberly, was about all these Trump transition emails that were seized by Robert Mueller's investigators. People say, you know what, that was overly aggressive move by the investigators, and then Mueller's teams said, hey, this is fair game. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, it depends on what side of it you come down on to say, OK, wait, this looks like tremendous overreach in terms of a big document and information grab to get a swath of information about pre-campaign, and during the campaign, and transition officials. I mean, even had Don Jr. going and testifying. And then he saw leaks right after that coming out by shifts. The whole thing to me is not coming off a very good at all because it just seems like there's a specific intended purpose to undermine the president. We're going to see what Mueller has to say. I don't think he's going to remove him whatsoever. There's nothing to hide. There is no collusion. Everyone has cooperated and testified. You're getting to the bottom of what was going on in this investigation and the unclean hands that are there. So let the truth come out, to silence it once and for all that they didn't do anything wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the president's lawyers, Dana, say that they expect this investigation to be wrapping up fairly soon.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm sure they hope so, and I think I hope so.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think we all hope so, except Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do think though -- if the Trump lawyers hadn't been surprised that these documents were obtained, then they would have actually been in a better position. I am surprised that they were surprised. When you work at a transition office and you are given a .gov email -- when you get the email you agree that all of those emails are subject to being able to search at any point. Just like an employer here, can come on and look at your Fox News account.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, they can't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I hope not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And so, if -- I think that the Trump team lawyers were really concerned these were taken inappropriately that they would go to the judge, not to congress, and to the court of public opinion to try to undermine it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And this seems to be a campaign in the court of public opinion, Juan, of trying to work the refs as they do in sports. You criticize and criticize, and hopefully it can have an effect.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think there's any question. I think that what this is. It's a whole propaganda campaign against Robert Mueller, against the Justice Department, against the FBI. Even as you have Trump officials like Jeff Sessions, the attorney general, like Christopher Wray, the FBI director, saying, no, these people are doing a good job. They're patriots and they're working hard to protect America. But just what we've heard last week, as the president was leaving was he said no collusion. He talks about himself, but he doesn't talk about all the aids that were involved in the campaign. And that's why I think a lot of people were, Greg, thinking, oh, something is being set up here that would allow him to justify going after Robert Mueller. But I think now we even have a spat between Fox and Friends and Hannity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, don't say that. Don't say that. Not around the holidays.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I know, I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, it seems like the more, more Democrats investigate this president, the more crimes they find that they committed. Coming up, days before Christmas, thousands of flights grounded. How will you be impacted? Next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A Fox News alert. We are monitoring developments in a major train derailment in Washington State that left multiple people dead and injured. The Amtrak train jumped the tracks and part of it crashed down on to a highway. Dan Springer is on the scene with the latest. Dan?

utterances.speaker: DAN SPRINGER, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And Dana, that death toll stands at six, according to the Associated Press. A national transportation safety board go team is in route to Washington State from Washington, D.C., and we expect them to be here this afternoon and fully here by this evening. If I step out of the way, you can see that we now have a lot of large equipment, caterpillars and other equipment that will eventually be used to take those train cars off of interstate 5 here in DuPont, Washington, which is about 50 miles south of Seattle. Several of these cars jumped the tracks and fell onto vehicles that were southbound on I-5, killing six people. All those who were killed were in the train. Nobody on the ground, nobody in cars below were killed, but 77 people were taken to local hospitals. They have, obviously, various degrees of injuries. This was an inaugural trip for this Amtrak train which connects Seattle to Portland. It was meant to be a high-speed train that would shave 15 minutes off of the travel between those two cities. It's a more direct route, but it also has a sharper curve here. So an NTSB investigators get on the scene, they will obviously be looking at the speed at which that train was traveling. There's also been an unconfirmed report of an obstruction on the track. Again, all the things the NTSB investigators will be looking out when they get here. In the meantime, we have a lot of equipment assembled here. The goal, once the investigators get here is to clean up this scene and get this interstate reopened as quickly as possible. This is a major artery that goes all the way from Canada to Mexico, and 60,000 vehicles passed through here southbound each day. So they want to get this open up as quickly as possible. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Dan, thank you so much. Meanwhile, on another story we're following, power is now finally restored in Hartsfield Jackson Atlanta International Airport after plunging into darkness yesterday, grounding over 1,000 fights and causing a holiday travel nightmare across the country. Officials say a fire in an underground electrical facility is responsible for bringing the world's largest airport to a standstill. So Kimberly, did you see this yesterday? The power goes out at 1 p.m. It's not restored fully until midnight. Everybody is trapped.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, and I saw the pictures of everybody at the airport. And they're, like, in darkness and just, like, piled up on, like, luggage. You couldn't tell the difference between Samsonite and humans. Very interesting to me. But you know, it really sucks during the holidays when you have this kind of, like, you know, disaster happen when you're trying to get to see loved ones, and then get rerouted. And like, what are you going to do and what about your hotel? And are they going to care.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or finish out your last week at work before the holiday.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The whole thing. And so it's very challenging, especially, I mean, Atlanta is a hugely busy -- busy, busy airport. I mean, it's unbelievable the amount of international flights and traffic coming in and out of there. So I mean, just think about it. It's like the equivalent of something happening...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, even though apparently -- well, they don't know what happened, Greg. They don't think it was anything. Nobody...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Cyber terror.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... messed with it or cyber terror. But I did think that it shows just how easily disrupted our lives are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It could be artificial intelligence pretending it's an accident...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Robots, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ... already self-aware, are doing these little tests. This actually is, like you said, it's a nice dry run on how an attack on our grid might look and feel, except if you enlarge it to entire states and extend the duration and differently. Because you don't need to invade a country if you just have the humans in the country turn on themselves. Which I mean, if that went on another day, you know, people would be -- people would be eating each other, Dana. No, it's like they would open up a -- get out free food. The one thing, though, is like, this is why I always do carry-on, and I always have booze and a book and an iPod.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And pills.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If stuff goes bad, I just leave. I just go, "You know what?"

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's amazing. I think I would have left, too. Because Juan, I know a lot of people couldn't necessarily get out of the airport. They didn't have anywhere to go. But if you had an option, would you have left? Everybody looked very calm.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And no chargers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No chargers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It wasn't -- it wasn't, you know, pitch black. It was that they didn't have power. They had emergency generators. But the problem was, and especially, I relate to this with some intensity, that if you flew in during this period, they were told you can't get to the gate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's the worst part.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can't operate all the stuff that's...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... necessary for you to get off the plane. So they had people just sitting on the plane for hours. It's terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, God. Imagine that bathroom.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, the bathroom thing. I was thinking about that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Forget about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, did you know that...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... Chick-Fil-A is usually closed on Sundays. They opened, and they delivered food to stranded passengers after Atlanta's mayor called for assistance around 10 p.m. So they opened up and got the job done.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would have just pretended I was stranded just to get free Chick-Fil-A.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You've done worse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here are my travel tips.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Travel insurance, buy it. There's a little box you can check whenever you buy a flight or a hotel.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's not that expensive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's only, like, ten or 15 or $20.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I recommend that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Greg and I were talking about Clear.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Clear is like TSA precheck on steroids. You don't have to do anything except put your irises on a little thing. It's like James Bond.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Isn't that just, like, Washington?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You go right to the front.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Like D.C. has it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They've expanded it into other hubs. And then the Delta Lounge, I know it's pricey, but you don't have to hang out with everybody else. And you can just eat all that free food.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Elitist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And drink free booze.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The rabble. You don't want to be near the rabble, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: By the way, now everyone's going to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I love this. And lastly, the whole thing that your parents tell you when you go for a flight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fresh underwear?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Get there three hours before an international.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Two hours before domestic. No, one hour before domestic. 1.5 before international. Stop clogging the place up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're clogging it up. That is the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They're clogging it up, but I have to strongly second the Delta Lounge.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, well, aren't we special?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: People go there...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have to second the fresh pair of underwear, wherever you go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... trying to meet people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They just go there to meet you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. At all times. All right. Well, we're glad the power is back on. When we return, this "Saturday Night Live" comedian is serious about showing his permanent love for Hillary Clinton. We'll explain.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Time for... {BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's Just Too Easy!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's Just Too Easy!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great music, eh? Welcome to "It's Just Too Easy." It's when we do a story that's just too easy to ridicule, making it too hard to ignore. So in this episode, Pete Davidson -- he's the nice kid from "Saturday Night Live" -- just got a tattoo of Hillary on his arm. When his friends asked him why, he said it was because Hillary was a badass. So now he has something in common with Hillary: They both have an ass on their arm. Hers was named Bill. See, it's just too easy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now, I could say that this is the funniest thing Peter has ever done, but that's just too easy. I could say this is the funniest thing to come out of "SNL" this year, but that's just too easy. I could just laugh hysterically at this completely inaccurate likeness of Hillary. But that's just too easy. So maybe it's better to ask why would you get a tattoo of Hillary when there are so many other more preferable options? Like a gorgeous dolphin. Look at that. Or maybe a delightful unicorn. That is so special. Or why not just me? Yes. Look at that. It's beautiful. Everyone should have me on their body -- tattoowise.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Uh-oh. Someone might.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Anyway, Pete, we get it. You care. You are morally superior, but woefully transparent in your appeasement. Tattoos like this illustrate that decisions based on feelings always end with something you really regret. Like choosing Hillary as your candidate, because it felt great to nominate a woman. She lost and yet tattoos are easier to disappear.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's funny.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just wanted to do this story so we could talk about tattoos. I'm going to start with you, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you get a tattoo on your body, what tattoo would it be?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think, you know, I'm not for tattoos.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, no?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But this is pretend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would go with my main man, Jasper.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I knew it!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So cute.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you actually had this done this morning. That's great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's not my arm.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You have a very hairy arm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's another reason I'm terrified of the tattoo. Doesn't it hurt terribly?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it does. But that's why you get drunk. You do tons of shots and a couple pain pills. Everything is great, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's every day for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Anyway, we won't get into that here. Your tattoo, if you could.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: First of all, I have no tattoos on my body. Like Dana, I don't do them. Not going to happen. However, to play along...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... or role-play, as they say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's what they say.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: For this segment...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Careful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you never role play.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No. I would definitely get Ronan, my little munchkin, Ro-Dog. What a cutie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know the guy that -- the model we used for this, has tattoos all over his body. And then we kicked him out of the building. And we said, "Thanks." Paid him 50 bucks. All right, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And that would be on my shoulder.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Shoulder.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I just want to make that clear to anyone who might be freaked out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Jesse, I'm dying to know what tattoo you would get.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I put a lot of thought into this, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I came up with Dr. Sebastian Gorka.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Gorka.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think he'd look great on any appendage.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Eww!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's you know -- there's something terrifying about him but also really wholesome. He's, like, the most fascinating man. You know that commercial with the beer?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Most interesting...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, he's just fascinating on many levels.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... interesting man in the world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it would be a nice conversation piece.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Women would like it. Men would like it. I mean, what's not to like?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What if he gets arrested for some horrible crime?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Even better.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's like having the Hillary tattoo. You regret it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You regret it. All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You can change it to Hillary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, what is your tattoo?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think there's much doubt about it. If Pete's going to get Hillary, I've got to do something, you know, as a FOX News guy, what can I do?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I've got to get a triple. I've got to do everybody. There's Hannity. There's Laura Ingraham and Jeanine Pirro. In fact, I really wanted the girls on either side of Hannity, because I wanted, like, a propaganda special.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is fair and balanced.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is absolutely incredible.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think it's actually quite attractive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Did you like that one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I got a tattoo. Actually, this is actually on me. I got a tattoo of Tattoo from "Fantasy Island" hanging out from the Russian -- hanging out with the Russian pop star duo TaTu. There they are, all together, and they all have their hands up. Isn't it pleasant? You have Tattoo and Tatu, together.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That was interesting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is interesting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Congratulations to the guy who got all the tattoos.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'd like to thank Sean O'Rourke for -- I gave him an unusual mission on Monday. You know Roger Stone has a tattoo of Nixon on his back.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I won't tell you how I found out, but it's interesting.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It was called your Saturday night.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. No, I watched -- it was some -- I watched a documentary.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It is. You see it in a documentary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Big weekend plans, huh, Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know it. All right. Up next, the real-life hunt for E.T. Glad they're going after that punk. New details about a $20 million top- secret military UFO program when we return.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh. I guess we're not alone after all. A stunning new revelation. The Pentagon reportedly set up a secret program ten years ago looking for UFOs deep in space. And newly-released video captured by U.S. Navy pilots offers an inside look at this secretive government program. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: There's a whole fleet of them. Look.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: My gosh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: "My gosh" is right. I mean, who would believe? So the thing is, we don't know if this is a UFO. It could be, like, somebody's aircraft that wasn't reported. But this really gives a lot of credence to people who've been saying, "Hey, the government was hiding something from us." You're shaking your head?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, because we already know there's nothing out there because a couple of reasons. One, we have had this incredible revolution with digital cameras and smartphones. We spend all this time looking -- as a child, looking at these grainy photographs that we used to look at as kids and documentaries. Well, we don't get any more of that. And people -- everybody has a phone, and we don't see anymore. The reason why there has been no contact is because they aren't -- they do not exist. And they don't exist, because we don't exist. We go out and we look at the lifeless orbs, these planets out there, that's what we look like to them, because this is is all a computer simulation that basically was created long ago. Those planets out there are already conquered and simulated, which is why there's only us.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is he OK?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just changed my mind. I think Greg is an alien. I think you're the alien.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am a shapeshifting lizard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, anyway...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Now you're going to encourage people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was struck that in fact, you know, ten years, and they put 22 million bucks into this, Dana. So do you think this is a waste, or does this justify what the government was doing?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In the scheme of things, for as much money as the government spends, I think that this is not money that was poorly spent. I do think that it was -- it was Harry Reid, the senator from Nevada, who got this money earmarked into the DIA budget, which is a secret budget for the intelligence agencies and the Defense Department. But he had support from Senator Ted Stevens, who said, "I think we ought to look into this."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, why? Because he got hit by a UFO.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was an unidentified flying object.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You mean Harry Reid?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, when he...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hurt his eye.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. The exercise equipment?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I liked that joke.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I listened to an interview this morning with -- on "The Daily," the New York Times podcast. They interviewed the guy who just recently left his position. What was he, Ando (ph), I think his name was?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And he says, like -- he's not saying there's for sure something out there but that it's definitely worth studying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Jesse, there was the video. It's not like we don't know. I mean, now you're looking at something just like the pilot, and you're saying what is that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I can't identify what that is, Juan. I have no idea. But I've gone to these UFO conventions back in the day and shot "Watters' World," and people tell me stories about being abducted.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They believe any of this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They honestly believe they were abducted and things were done to them while aboard the spacecraft. And a lot of the stories share similar details. So there has to be something going on. I don't think everybody is hallucinating.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, they are. It's hypnogogic nightmares. Everybody, they're hypnogogic nightmares. When you're in sleep paralysis, and you think something is on top of you, that's a hypnogogic nightmare.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But I do think spending a lot of money on stuff like this has other benefits. You know? Like obviously, when the military industrial complex spends this amount of money on things, isn't that how they created the Internet? Not Al Gore.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You never know what you might discover.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What you just said is absolutely true. But Kimberly, I'm accustomed to sort of mocking these people as tin hat -- tinfoil hat brigade, I think they call them, or people who are just making -- you know, if you ever listen to Art Bell in the middle of the night on the radio. All these things, you think what? This guys is -- but he's entertaining. Now I'm thinking maybe there's something going on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, look, there's been enough discussion about it that it makes sense they're going to study it or figure it out. Even President Trump said he wants to know about, you know, Area 51 and the secrets of it. It was, like, a good reason to become president, right, get all the top-secret information. Just like with the JFK files. I don't know. I mean, listen, I have an open mind about things. I also enjoy astrology.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Very nice. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's your sign?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Pisces.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ooh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Time for...

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Talking Animal News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Talking Animal News." You know, working at FOX, a lot of people send me some interesting things. I'll get something like leather socks one day, and then I'll get homemade meat the next, which I love to eat so keep sending it. And every now and then I get a talking animal. And somebody sent me a -- looks like I believe it might be a hamster. And it had an interesting message for us. Roll it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I'm Jesse Watters the hamster. I have 27 brothers and sisters. And my mom still hates me the most.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very good, Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I wonder if it's somebody we know who sent that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Jerry Pentacoli (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't get it. Whoever sent it is probably on some kind of power trip.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's pretty cute, though, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. So today marks the 20th anniversary of the death of one of our favorite comedians. Christopher Farley. That's right, died of a drug overdose in his apartment at age 33. You know, "SNL" guy, was along with Chris Rock, Adam Sandler, Rob Schneider, David Spade and one of my favorite movies, "Tommy Boy."

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER FARLEY, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: Fat guy in a little coat. Fat guy in a little coat.

utterances.speaker: DAVID SPADE, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: I'm serious.

utterances.speaker: FARLEY
utterances.utterance: Richard, what's happening? Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We all still miss him today. And he appeared in a lot of "Watters' Worlds." So thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Aww. Sweet, Jesse. You're touched.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Literally.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Careful.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're waiting on me. All right. Visions of sugar plums dancing in your head for the holidays? Well, not so much for Luke Skywalker, a.k.a. actor Mark Hamill. He's still upset that the FCC voted last week to repeal net neutrality. He's particularly incensed that the FCC chairman, Ajit Pai, dressed up as a Jedi in a video to endorse the repeal. Hamill tweeted at him, saying, "You are profoundly unworthy to wield a lightsaber. A Jedi you are not."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my. The force is not with you, Mr. Chairman.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: How crazy is that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They really are picking on that guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They are.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're going after his family.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Remember, not only a Jedi; he dressed up as Santa.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They guy -- they hate him more than they hate ISIS. It's ridiculous, these people.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's so nuts. OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. So you know most babies start walking around the age of 1. But Cash Rally thought that was too easy. Check her out. So she started -- she's from Idaho. She started walking at nine months. And her parents are big outdoor enthusiasts, so they had her get on a snowboard and took it around the house, and then she hit the slopes. And she was able to do it at 1 years old.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Check her out. Cash Rally. And they're going to try to go to Costa Rica in February and get her up on surfboard, too. So we look forward to those.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No helmet?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's pretty good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No helmet? Oh, it's just a baby with a soft head. Yes, that's smart.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's pretty cute.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Helmets are for snowflakes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nicely done.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh. These two, sensitivity training. OK, perfect. So I have a book to promote. No, not one of my own, like Greg does. But one for Chris McKinley, former Navy SEAL, and Andy Simon. They have a new book out called "Enemy in the Wire." And it's perfect for anyone interested in military life, specifically. Andy grew up in a navy family. And then, as I said, Chris is one of our fearless warriors with the Navy SEALs. And it's a follow-up to Andy's first novel. "My Father's Son" is a behind-the-scenes look at the Special Ops community and what it takes to be part of that brotherhood and tells the story of one boy, of one family who has their world ripped apart by war. It's actually going to be preordered on Amazon, but it's out officially in March, just in time for my birthday. Congratulations.

utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.utterance: I'm in. I'm not in, no. I'll watch you guys get them, though.
